contentrichtext.text: {{other people}} {{Infobox person |name = Richard Barton |image = Richard_Barton_grave.JPG |caption = The grave of Richard Barton |birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1790|08|30}} |birth_place = [[Newport, Isle of Wight]], [[England]] |death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1866|08|20|1790|08|30}} |death_place = [[Trentham, New Zealand]] |other_names = |known_for = Early New Zealand settler, Establishment of Trentham |nationality = [[United Kingdom|British]] }} '''Richard Barton''' (30 August 1790 â€“ 20 August 1866) was the first European resident of [[Trentham, New Zealand|Trentham]], [[Upper Hutt]], in [[New Zealand]]. He was born in [[Newport, Isle of Wight]], [[England]].<ref>W. M. Smallfield, p10, ''Our First Hundred Years . . . .'', Parish of Trentham, New Zealand. Upper Hutt, 1962. Available online from [http://archives.uhcc.govt.nz/documentpopup.php?catalog=64&asset=14255 Upper Hutt City Library Digital Archive item 64/14255]</ref> ==Arrival in New Zealand== He arrived in Wellington in 1840 on the "Oriental", the second of four early settler ships, and in 1841 purchased 100-acres for a farm in the Upper [[Hutt Valley]].<ref>[http://www.upperhuttcity.com/page/29/Aboutourcity.boss Upper Hutt City website], retrieved 28 Dec 2010.</ref> He named his estate '''Trentham''' in honour of the [[Duke of Sutherland]], one of whose subsidiary titles is '''Viscount Trentham''', of [[Trentham, Staffordshire|Trentham]] in the County of [[Staffordshire|Stafford]]. (Before emigrating to New Zealand, Barton had been Supervisor at the then [[Trentham Hall]].) Much of his former estate is now [[Trentham Memorial Park]], which includes the native bush remnant known as [[Barton's Bush]]. The surrounding suburb of [[Trentham, New Zealand|Trentham]] also takes its name from his estate. Exactly when Barton and his family began living on the Trentham estate is unclear from various historical sources. Although he appears to have built a [[slab hut]] on his purchase around 1841, the Trentham Parish histories indicate that he and his third wife, Hannah, whom he married about 1843, only settled on the estate in 1846. During the intervening 5 years it seems Barton may have assisted, perhaps supervised, the surveying the surrounding country for the Wellington Company. The Barton homestead was located near the corner of the Main Road (now Fergusson Drive) and Camp Road (now Camp Street) and overlooked what is now Trentham Memorial Park.<ref>Information Board, Trentham Memorial Park</ref> Barton appears to have acquired more land, as his estate is described as lying to the west of the Main Road from Quinn's Post to Silverstream on both sides of the river. By 27 December 1861, Barton is described as the chief landowner and magistrate of the district. This being when arrangements were being made to establish an Anglican church mission at Trentham. Early in 1862 it appears that Barton extended his own house to accommodate the church missionaries as well as donating land for the establishment of a church. ==Death== Richard Barton died on 20 August 1866 and was buried in Upper Hutt at St John's Anglican Church cemetery.<ref>Upper Hutt City Library Photograph Collection P2-413-816 [http://archives.uhcc.govt.nz/assets.php/17/5848 Richard & Hannah Barton tomb at St John's Church Trentham], retrieved 28 Dec 2010.</ref><ref>[http://homepages.paradise.net.nz/stjohns3/html/history.html A Brief History of St John's Trentham], retrieved 28 Dec 2010.</ref> The Barton family still holds a plot in St Johns Church for Richard Barton's ancestors. ==Notes== {{Reflist}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Barton, Richard | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = Early New Zealand settler | DATE OF BIRTH = 30 August 1790 | PLACE OF BIRTH = Newport, Isle of Wight, England | DATE OF DEATH = 20 August 1866 | PLACE OF DEATH = Trentham, Upper Hutt, New Zealand }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Barton, Richard}} [[Category:People from the Isle of Wight]] [[Category:People from Upper Hutt]] [[Category:1790 births]] [[Category:1866 deaths]]
